title: My husband died 2 months ago and had a car lease under his name only... I return the car back to the dealer
question: Few days ago got a statement sent to my husband saying he has to pay the 12.000,for the remaining of the lease.Do I have to pay the amount??? My name is not at all on the lease agreement..
question_tags: Business contracts,Debt collection for businesses,Business insurance,Business life insurance,Business real estate,Commercial rental property,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Lease agreements for renting,Real estate,Business,Spousal debt,Marriage
answers:
1- Sorry for your loss.

2- It's entirely possible that the loan related to the lease had life insurance on it. Check with the lender.

3- No doubt the cookie thing is a great idea. Not sure how many car dealers would go for it, especially these days. They are really getting ruthless lately. They seem to prey more and more on the weak and helpless.

4- It is also correct that they should look to the "estate" if there was any and not you, as you did not sign on to the lease.

5- What it appears they are doing are treating this as a "repossession" and assuming a "purchase" at the end of the lease, otherwise, your payoff should be no more than lease payments, early termination fee and perhaps mileage and wear and again, prior counsel is correct, it should not be so high.

5a- The good news is that they cannot unilaterally assume a purchase and that they need to jump through a good number of hoops to come up with that number and from the sound of it, they did not.

5b- Moreover, knowingly trying to collect from you, a non-signatory widow is a violation of multiple fair debt collection laws and could cost them dearly, should you have any willingness to take them head on in a lawsuit at this difficult time in your life.

I hope this input was helpful in some way...

In California, the vehicle creditor has one year from the date of your husband's death in which to file a lawsuit against you for collection of this debt. I would not recommend that you pay anything on this debt until you have spoken to an experienced debtor's rights attorney.

It depends. They cannot keep the car and collect the full lease contract. They might be able to enforce the the few months of accrued payments, and any excessive wear. It is unlikely that they lost 12,000 of value when you returned the vehicle, unless it was a Mercedes SL63 or Tesla Roadster. Take some PB Cookies and talk to the Lease Manager nicely. If they blow you off, leave a truthful but adverse Review on Trustlink. You can always take it down or make it more favorable if they get Religion. You can also make a Formal Complaint to Better Business Bureau.

The more technical answer is that your husband's Estate is liable for any existing debts, to the extent that there is assets to satisfy the debts. Basically, you only get what is left over after after his debts are paid from his assets. Consult an Estate and Trusts Attorney if Joe Blow Auto Dealer decides to fleece you for the returned car, after you make a BBB Complaint and Trustlink review.
